definition[0]: to sell something, especially for a cheap price, because you need the money or because you want to get rid of it
example[0]: After the war, we had to sell off part of the farm.
example[1]: We sell off leftover cakes before we close.
definition[1]: to sell all or part of an industry or company
example[2]: The Leicestershire company has sold off many of its smaller branches to cut debts.
definition[2]: the sale of an industry that the government owns, to private companies or other people
definition[3]: the sale of a lot of stocks or shares, which makes the price decrease
definition[4]: to sell all or most of an industry, company, business etc, usually at a low price
example[3]: He plans to break the company up and sell it off as several independent businesses.
example[4]: The privatization of state enterprises will be delayed until they can be sold off at a better price.
definition[5]: a situation in which many investors sell their bonds, shares etc, often very quickly
example[5]: In an otherwise calm market, there were steep sell-offs in shares.
definition[6]: when a business, company etc is sold to another company
example[6]: 6,000 metal union workers occupied two shipbuilding companies to protest at their planned sell-offs.
